column1: Treinta y Tres (Spanish pronunciation: [ˈtɾejnta i ˈtɾes]) is the capital city of the Treinta y Tres Department in eastern Uruguay.
The city is located on Route 8
column2: on the north banks of Olimar Grande River. The city is almost surrounded by a populated rural area
column4: known as Ejido de Treinta y Tres.

column1: Its name means "Thirty Three" and refers to the 19th-century national heroes
column3: who established the independence of Uruguay. Coincidentally
column4: the city is located near the 33°S line of latitude

column1: On 10 March 1853 it was declared a "Pueblo" (village) by the Act of Ley Nº 307 and on 20 September 1884 it was made capital of the department created by Ley Nº 1.754. According to the Act of Ley Nº 3.544
column2: on 19 July 1909 it held the status of "Villa" (town)
column3: which was elevated to "Ciudad" (city) on 29 September 1915 by the Act of Ley 5.335.

column2: Treinta y Tres had a population of 25
column3: 477. It is by far the largest town in what is a sparsely populated department. Together with Ejido de Treinta y Tres and the southwestern suburb of Villa Sara
column4: they form a population centre of around 33

column1: St. Joseph the Worker Parish Church (Roman Catholic)
Parish Church of Our Lady of the Thirty-Three (Roman Catholic)
Parish Church of the Holy Savior (Roman Catholic)
The climate in this area is characterized by hot
column2: humid summers and generally mild to cool winters.  According to the Köppen Climate Classification system
column3: Treinta y Tres has a humid subtropical climate
